Title: Siapakah Alicia Machado yang mengaku diolok 'Miss Piggy' oleh Trump?
Text: Hak atas foto AP Image caption Alicia Machado terpilih sebagai Miss Universe pada 1996 dan mengklaim diolok oleh Trump.Seorang mantan Miss Universe menjadi topik dalam debat pertama calon presiden Amerika Serikat dari Partai Republik Donald Trump dan Partai Demokrat Hillary Clinton.Dalam debat pertama calon presiden Amerika Serikat ini, Clinton menuduh Trump memperlakukan perempuan dengan sangat buruk termasuk klaim bahwa ia pernah menghina Alicia Machado dengan menyebutnya "Miss Piggy" (Nona Babi) setelah berat badannya naik menyusul kontes ratu kecantikan itu.Clinton juga mengatakan Trump pernah menyebut Miss Universe 1996 yang lahir di Venezuela itu sebagai "Miss Housekeeping" (Nona Rumah Tangga).Trump yang saat itu termasuk pemilik perusahaan yang menyelenggarakan Miss Universe juga dilaporkan menyebutnya "mesin makan".Machado muncul dalam video kampanye Clinton setelah debat Senin (26/09).Debat pertama calon presiden Amerika Serikat ini dikicaukan sekitar lima juta kali dan 62% di antaranya tentang Trump.Image caption "Terima kasih Hillary Clinton telah menyebut saya dalam debat."Machado melakukan diet pada 1997 setelah mengatakan ia bertambah berat badannya. Trump mengatakan dalam satu acara bahwa "ia suka makan, seperti kita semua" dan mendukung upaya dietnya dengan meminta Machado melakukan senam di depan pers.Di sela tiap menitDalam debat yang berlangsung panas, Clinton menegur Trump yang tidak menyebut nama mantan ratu kecantikan ini dengan mengatakan, "Donald, dia punya nama. Namanya Alicia Machado dan dia telah menjadi warga negara Amerika Serikat, dan dia akan ikut memilih pada bulan November ini," kata Clinton.Image caption Machado mengatakan secara terbuka ia akan memilih Clinton dalam pemilihan presiden.Trump meminta rincian lebih lanjut tentang tuduhan itu namun tidak segera menyanggahnya.Melalui akun Twitternya, Machado menyatakan "Terima kasih kepada Clinton karena telah menyebut saya dalam debat."Ia juga menulis, "Saya telah menerima paspor saya! Saya siap untuk memilih bagi negara saya, untuk Anda @HillaryClinton, untuk putri saya, untuk pekerja perempuan."Dalam debat pertama ini, cara Trump menghadapi saingan perempuannya ini juga banyak dikomentari, terutama terkait berapa kali ia melakukan interupsi.Trump pertama kali menginterupsi Clinton dan melakukannya hampir tiap menit dalam 25 menit pertama, menurut data oleh Vox."Salah, salah, salah," kata Trump dalam salah satu tanggapan dan dalam satu kesempatan sempat menceletuk "tidak."Image caption "Clinton menghadapi interupsi setiap .0007 detik dengan sangat bagus. Perempuan tampaknya terbiasa, laki-laki mencoba menyalip.Secara total, Vox mengatakan Clinton menginterupsi 17 kali sementara Trump 51 kali."Seorang calon pria tak boleh terlihat menakut-nakuti seorang perempuan," kata Jennifer Lawless, profesor pada Schoold of Public Affairs, American University."Apakah itu dengan lambaian tangan atau mendengus atau dengan gerakan mata, itu dapat dianggap sikap superioritas, karena dia adalah perempuan."Sementara Clinton sendiri tampaknya tegas dan tidak membiarkan Trump untuk menginterupsinya.
Description: Seorang mantan ratu kecantikan menjadi topik dalam debat pertama calon presiden Amerika Serikat dari Partai Republik Donald Trump dan Partai Demokrat Hillary Clinton. Alicia Machado pernah mengaku diolok 'Miss Piggy' oleh Trump.

Title: Katy Waldman‰Ûªs 10 Favorite Books of 2016
Text: Photo illustration by Slate. Images by Amazon* * *AdvertisementTraister was an indispensable voice during the 2016 election, writing about Hillary Clinton with warmth, lucidity, and insight. All three qualities are on display in her extraordinarily researched, cogently argued investigation into the rise of the single woman, which examines how unmarried women have long spearheaded social change and tracks the uneven line from past progressive movements to our current feminist flourishing. (I only wish she could have included a post-Trump addendum.) Especially notable is Traister‰Ûªs attention to the full racial and economic spectrum of womanhood and to the oft-underrated bonds of female friendship.Heat and Light by Jennifer Haigh. Ecco.In this sensitive and sweeping novel, Haigh returns to the fictional Bakerton, a mining village overtaken by ‰ÛÏfracking frenzy‰Û in the late 2010s. The locals are divided over whether to lease their land to an unscrupulous energy company; transient drillers flood into the bars with their lusts and sorrows; activists descend; salesmen make bargains with the townsfolk, the devil, and themselves. By the end of the book‰Ûªs 430 pages, Haigh‰Ûªs patient, cumulative arguments (about greed, faith, chance, and community) have achieved real sonority, and we feel fully invested in her individual characters. Heat and Light is that rare ‰ÛÏambitious social novel‰Û whose interlocking pieces are as vividly and precisely realized as its panoramic themes.AdvertisementModern Lovers by Emma Straub. Riverhead.Read Slate‰Ûªs review.As she demonstrated with her witty The Vacationers, Straub has charm to spare. In Modern Lovers, an ensemble novel about more-or-less forlorn fortysomethings in twee Brooklyn, her trademark nimbleness serves a story of startling emotional depth. Straub‰Ûªs adult characters (some of whom played together in a punk band) can‰Ûªt quite relinquish the dream of youth; their children don‰Ûªt know how to grow up, either. Disruptions small and large break across their interconnected paths, and there is deep satisfaction in watching an author as psychologically astute and empathetic as Straub play out their various responses. But the purest joys of the novel come from rooting for these relatably rudderless people as they attempt to sail into maturity with a modicum of grace.Moonglow by Michael Chabon. Harper.Read Slate‰Ûªs review.Again, you may be shocked‰ÛÓshocked!‰ÛÓto learn that the latest novel from Pulitzer Prize‰ÛÒwinning author Chabon, a shimmering ‰ÛÏmemoir‰Û about his grandparents, is among the year‰Ûªs best. But the pleasure of surrendering to Chabon‰Ûªs remarkable skills as a storyteller can‰Ûªt be overstated. He excels on every level: his gorgeous, funny, looping sentences; his knack for the harlequin escapade; his deft swerves into emotional honesty and power; his intuitive mastery of suspense, tension, and release. Plus, American hero Ramon the cat deserves all the accolades for his third-act moment of bravery. Go Ramon!AdvertisementMy Name Is Lucy Barton by Elizabeth Strout. Random House.In Strout‰Ûªs deceptively quiet hands, a line of dialogue can seem simple or commonplace until it begins to burn, a glowing coal plucked from the furnace of some character‰Ûªs psyche. My Name Is Lucy Barton is a masterpiece of slow-dawning meaning, an interrogation of family relationships that takes as its occasion an older woman‰Ûªs visit to the bedside of her convalescent daughter. (And that‰Ûªs all I‰Ûªm going to say about the plot!)Night of the Animals by Bill Broun. Ecco.In the England of 2052, an authoritarian king lords over a broken, drug-addled society, while the internet plays directly on people‰Ûªs corneas and suicide cultists seek salvation in the murder of animals. Homeless, nonagenarian addict Cuthbert believes he can save the world by releasing the creatures in the London Zoo, a task that plunges him deep into Celtic myth, the intrigues of the dystopian police state, and the scattered phantasms of his buried past. Broun‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBrexit novel,‰Û acquiring new resonance under the sign of Trump, is an eerie, wildly original debut‰ÛÓa blur of beauty and madness, like van Gogh‰Ûªs Starry Night.AdvertisementThis novel‰ÛÓabout an academic malcontent; his accidentally revolutionary mother; and the constellation of students, family members, blowhard politicians, reactionary cops, video game addicts, ghosts, and Norwegian hobgoblins encircling them‰ÛÓis a Thanksgiving banquet of a book, a narrative table groaning with dishes both delicious and overdone. Hill, a gifted satirist whose lambasting of special-snowflake millennials and escapist gamer nerds can feel too broad, slips in tone from intelligent and realist to zanily experimental to lush and dreamy. His 600-page opus is an extravaganza of talent, a beautiful and idiosyncratic mess that for all its flashiness finds its most expressive voice when exploring basic human themes: love, anger, loneliness, regret.In Winters‰Ûª speculative portrait of present-day America, slavery persists in four states (the ‰ÛÏHard Four‰Û), and hypercompetent government agents track down fugitives with the amoral aplomb of James Bond. One such operative is Victor, a freed slave whose nightmarish past keeps erupting into his detective work. The book is profligate with its noir tropes, funny, gripping, imaginative, and inexorable as it gradually unmasks the unthinkable evil at its core. The storyline, in other words, doubles as a descent‰ÛÓand there is always further down to go.AdvertisementWhitehead, who won this year‰Ûªs National Book Award for fiction, isn‰Ûªt hurting for laurels‰ÛÓand yet it‰Ûªs hard to imagine drafting a list of 2016‰Ûªs mightiest books without including this phantasmagorical slash into the dark gut of American racism. Cora, an escaped slave, travels through the South on a literal subterranean train, each stop an object lesson in a different ghoulish facet of white supremacy. Her resolve and dignity are moving‰ÛÓbut it‰Ûªs the author‰Ûªs playfulness and unpredictability that elevate this traditional tale of hardship into something singular, fugitive, and strange.This memoir, from a literary-minded neurosurgeon who is diagnosed with terminal bone cancer in his 30s, is poetic and generous, intimate and profound. In clear and flowing prose, Kalanithi describes his self-formation as a doctor and then the evaporation of that identity as he becomes, again, a patient, starving for time. If some sections of the book are rougher or more abstract than others, the overall work recalls a world of almost pre-Christian luminousness, in which classical concepts like virtue, honor, and excellence still have purchase, chance or fate reigns supreme, and no person can evade the dark forever.---Heat and Light: A Novel Check out this great listen on Audible.com. Title: Why Glenn Beck Really Hates Steve Bannon
Text: There has been something delightfully ironic about watching Glenn Beck become one of the sanest voices in conservative media over this past year.The Texas-based right-wing radio host and founder of The Blaze website‰ÛÓwho once declared that Barack Obama has a ‰ÛÏdeep-seated hatred for white people‰Û‰ÛÓwas #NeverTrump from the beginning of the GOP primaries. He initially threw his weight behind Ted Cruz and didn‰Ûªt budge from his anti-Trump stance even after Cruz decided to endorse the man who insulted his wife and blamed his father for the JFK assassination.As Election Day approached, Beck openly toyed with the idea of voting for Hillary Clinton, criticized Trump during the third presidential debate for his baffling incoherence on abortion, and called FBI Director James Comey ‰ÛÏirresponsible‰Û for tossing an October grenade into the race at the last minute.Throughout the race, however, Beck has reserved his harshest words for Steve Bannon, who just this weekend was named President-elect Trump‰Ûªs chief strategist. But is Beck‰Ûªs great moral outrage over the self-proclaimed leader of the alt-right as selfless as it seems? Or is it personal?It was all the way back in February of this year, when Cruz still had a chance and months before Trump had hired Bannon to serve as his campaign CEO, that Beck launched his attack.‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm telling you that I believe that Bannon thinks he‰Ûªs either going to be the chief of staff or he‰Ûªs going to be the next Roger Ailes,‰Û Beck said, presciently. He accused the Breitbart executive chairman of ‰ÛÏtaking orders from a political candidate‰Û and ‰ÛÏreworking your entire site to promote the lies of a specific candidate without any kind of truth behind these things.‰Û In Beck‰Ûªs view, that made Bannon more like Joseph Goebbels than Ailes.‰ÛÏAndrew Breitbart would be spinning in his grave right now,‰Û Beck said, referring to the late founder of Breitbart.com.But as it turns out, neither Breitbart nor Bannon were big fans of Beck, who launched The Blaze as a direct competitor to Breitbart after he was let go by Ailes and Fox News.A few months after Beck started broadcasting his GBTV show online in 2011, Andrew Breitbart went on Steve Bannon‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏVictory Sessions‰Û podcast, and the two men spent a good deal of time trashing their new competition.Beck had made some provocative comments comparing Newt Gingrich to Barack Obama and suggested Tea Partiers only liked Gingrich because he was white, and Breitbart and Bannon accused Beck of ‰ÛÏrace-baiting.‰Û‰ÛÏIn the past, Beck has made a lot of mistakes, and his supporters come out and try to defend him, because Beck is a coward and will not defend himself when he makes a mistake or lies about a person or steals content,‰Û Breitbart said.Egging him on, Bannon replied, ‰ÛÏHold on, I want to go back over this: You‰Ûªre saying that Glenn Beck‰Ûªs a coward, Glenn Beck‰Ûªs a liar, and you‰Ûªre saying that Glenn Beck steals material from people?‰ÛGet The Beast In Your Inbox! Daily Digest Start and finish your day with the top stories from The Daily Beast. Cheat Sheet A speedy, smart summary of all the news you need to know (and nothing you don't). By clicking ‰ÛÏSubscribe,‰Û you agree to have read the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy Subscribe Thank You! You are now subscribed to the Daily Digest and Cheat Sheet. We will not share your email with anyone for any reason.‰ÛÏOh yes, and this is well-documented,‰Û Breitbart said, laying out what he viewed as Beck‰Ûªs deliberately misleading coverage of the Shirley Sherrod scandal, which began its life on Breitbart‰Ûªs Big Government website. He went on to say that Beck has been known to ‰ÛÏtake countless bloggers‰Ûª content, to turn it into book gold, to turn it into chalkboard gold, his infamous chalkboards,‰Û an allegation explored in detail by The Daily Caller‰Ûªs Matthew Boyle earlier that year.Asked by Bannon what he would like to see Beck do next, Breitbart said, ‰ÛÏAt this point, I don‰Ûªt care what he does because he‰Ûªs dead to me.‰ÛFive years later, Bannon had officially joined the Trump campaign and Beck was openly calling him ‰ÛÏquite possibly the most dangerous guy in all of American politics‰Û and a ‰ÛÏhorrible, despicable human being.‰Û His assertion that Bannon uses the ‰ÛÏDark Web‰Û to exact revenge on his enemies landed Beck on Breitbart‰Ûªs list of the ‰ÛÏ six dumbest claims ‰Û journalists made about Bannon.After news broke that Bannon would be joining Trump in the White House, Beck once again warned against Bannon‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏclear tie to white nationalists,‰Û adding, ‰ÛÏHe‰Ûªs a terrifying man.‰ÛThese sentiments were echoed on Monday by Dana Loesch, who sued Breitbart‰ÛÓciting an ‰ÛÏincreasingly hostile‰Û work environment‰ÛÓbefore joining The Blaze, during her live show. ‰ÛÏSteve Bannon puts himself above everything,‰Û she said of her former boss. ‰ÛÏI just don‰Ûªt think this is a good fit for the country. Maybe it is for Steve Bannon, but it‰Ûªs not a good fit for the country.‰Û Loesch suggested that Bannon will enter the White House with ‰ÛÏvengeance‰Û and ‰ÛÏpettiness‰Û in his heart, which should alone ‰ÛÏdisqualify‰Û him from advising the president.When Beck first joked that Bannon was angling to be Trump‰Ûªs chief of staff earlier this year, he had no idea how right he would end up being. That job may have ended up going to Reince Priebus, but it was Bannon who got top billing on the official press release. In the end, Bannon‰Ûªs ambitions far exceeded being the next Roger Ailes.Now, a man who has never hid his disgust for Beck is about to become arguably the second most powerful person in Washington, if not the country. And at the same time, Trump and his team have made every indication that they intend to act hostilely toward a ‰ÛÏrigged‰Û media that they believe has been biased against them from the beginning.It is yet another irony that Beck now finds himself in their crosshairs along with the rest of us.
Description: The Blaze founder has become an unlikely voice of reason on the right. But what‰Ûªs really behind his grudge with Donald Trump‰Ûªs new chief strategist?

Title: BREAKING: Top Trump Adviser Drops Bombshell... Wednesday Is the END of Hillary's Campaign
Text: One of Donald Trump‰Ûªs top surrogates made news when he intimated that a WikiLeaks release of information on Hillary Clinton, which he says will happen Wednesday, could finish her campaign.In a Twitter posting this weekend, Trump adviser and Republican political consultant Roger Stone said that the information, which he says will be released Wednesday, will somehow end Hillary Clinton‰Ûªs campaign.‰ÛÏWednesday @Hillary Clinton is done. #Wikileaks,‰Û Stone tweeted.https://twitter.com/RogerJStoneJr/status/782443074874138624 ?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwThe information was originally scheduled to be released Tuesday, but NBC News (via Heat Street) reported WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange ordered the release pushed back due to ‰ÛÏsecurity concerns.‰ÛTRENDING: How Trump Brilliantly Screwed Over Red State Dem Senators with Kavanaugh NominationThose security concerns are hardly illusory, especially when one is dealing with the left. Back in 2010, when WikiLeaks published a huge trove of classified diplomatic cables that embarrassed the Obama administration and then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, liberal commentator Bob Beckel recommended that Assange be assassinated, suggesting during a Fox News television appearance that someone ‰ÛÏshoot the son of a bitch!‰ÛAssange also intimated after his organization‰Ûªs leak of Democratic National Committee documents that murdered DNC staffer Seth Rich had been one of the organization‰Ûªs sources. According to The Hill, that hasn‰Ûªt stopped the organization, which has said it plans to release more information on Clinton before the Nov. 8 election.It is unknown whether the delayed information will actually be released on Wednesday, but Stone seems to believe, from his tweet, that it will be.WikiLeaks‰Ûª most significant information dump on the Democrats, which occurred right before the Democratic National Convention in July, confirmed that the party organization was operating as a de facto arm of the Hillary Clinton campaign and was actively working to undermine the insurgent campaign of socialist Sen. Bernie Sanders.The emails also exposed coordination between the DNC and the media.How much more damaging are these emails than those that WikiLeaks has already released? Title: WATCH: Punk Tries to Ruin Concert for Vets, So Luke Bryan PUNCHES Him From Stage
Text: Country singer Luke Bryan performed at Nashville‰Ûªs Bridgestone Arena Wednesday as part of Charlie Daniel‰Ûªs 80th birthday all-star Volunteer Jam ‰ÛÓ a concert that raised money for military veterans, Taste of Country reported.Sadly, one concert-goer decided to make an obscene gesture, and Bryan didn‰Ûªt take it sitting down ‰ÛÓ he punched the man from the stage.In the middle of a song, a man in the front row decided to give Bryan the middle finger. Bryan reportedly yelled ‰ÛÏCome on,‰Û before he went ahead and punched the man, according to Us Weekly. Bryan then gathered himself and went on with his performance.Take a look at a video of the altercation below both on Twitter and an up-close version posted to YouTube:https://twitter.com/_kelseymeador/status/804188938265042944 ?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwAfter the altercation, Rolling Stone posted a statement from Bryan‰Ûªs team:‰ÛÏA man in (the) front row was making crude hand gestures toward Luke during his performance. It was insulting not only to him, but more importantly to the men, women and families sitting around him who were there to support and celebrate Charlie Daniels and the efforts of raising money for the military veterans ‰ÛÓ some of who were in the audience. The concert security personnel saw the man‰Ûªs disruptive actions of the event and he was escorted out.‰ÛThe obscene gesture was apparently the tip of the iceberg, according to Rolling Stone, which reported that there were two hecklers in the crowd, one with an insulting sign that referenced Bryan‰Ûªs famous tight jeans.Although it‰Ûªs not a great idea to punch a guy in the front row ‰ÛÓ if only for your own safety ‰ÛÓ it is understandable why Bryan did it. The event was meant to raise money for vets and the man‰Ûªs actions were extremely disrespectful.Fortunately, as Taste of Country reported, the man was escorted out by security and the event wasn‰Ûªt hampered ‰ÛÓ $240,000 was raised that night for the Journey Home Project which works to help veteran‰Ûªs lives in a variety of ways.To behave like that person did is unacceptable ‰ÛÓ especially at an event to raise money for veterans. Title: Samsung raided in Park corruption probe
Text: Image copyright Reuters Image caption Ms Park has seen her approval ratings plummet amid the scandalSouth Korean authorities have raided the offices of Samsung and the national pension fund as part of a corruption investigation linked to the president.They are probing whether Park Geun-hye pressured the fund to support a Samsung merger, said the Yonhap news agency.In return, Samsung is alleged to have given financial favours to Ms Park's confidante Choi Soon-sil, Yonhap said.The scandal has led to growing calls for Ms Park's resignation, but she has said the allegations are "fantasy".Ms Choi, who has been charged with coercion and attempted fraud, is accused of using her close relationship with Ms Park to obtain favours and funds for her own gain.Earlier this week prosecutors said Ms Park had a "considerable" role in the scandal.The allegations have enraged the South Korean public, and caused Ms Park's approval ratings to plummet. However, she has resisted the calls for her to resign and has yet to agree to be questioned by investigators.Her spokesman rejected the prosecutors' case as speculation built on "a house of fantasy".Image copyright EPA Image caption South Koreans have staged demonstrations calling for Ms Park's resignationSamsung's offices had already been raided over related allegations.Wednesday's raid had to do with a merger last year between the electronics giant's construction arm, Samsung C&T, and an affiliate firm, Cheil Industries.The deal went through despite significant opposition from shareholders, who said it would hurt minority shareholders while benefiting the family of Samsung's group owner Lee Kun-hee.South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS), which owns stakes in both companies, sealed the deal by voting in favour of it.Prosecutors allege that Samsung gave ‰âÂ2.8m euros ($3.1m;å£2.5m) to a company co-owned by Ms Choi and her daughter, in return for Ms Park's support for the deal.Samsung was also among several conglomerates that gave millions of dollars to two non-profit foundations owned by Ms Choi, after the latter allegedly pressured them for donations.Samsung and the pension fund confirmed the raids without giving further details.Image copyright AFP/Getty Images Image caption At the centre of the probe is Choi Soon-sil, a close confidante of Park Geun-hyeMs Park is accused of giving Ms Choi inappropriate access to government policy-making and decisions.She has since acknowledged that she committed lapses, and apologised twice on national television.Separately on Wednesday, Ms Park's office confirmed a report that they had bought hundreds of Viagra pills on behalf of the president.A spokesman told reporters that the drug, better known for treating erectile dysfunction among men, was meant to help Ms Park and her staff cope with high-altitude sickness during trips to Africa.
Description: Prosecutors have raided Samsung and the national pension fund as part of a corruption probe.

Title: Sorry, I gotta get this off of my chest.
Text: They deserve so much better than Trump.Anybody who knows me knows that I‰Ûªm not easily offended. Part of it is past job and sports decisions I‰Ûªve made. If you‰Ûªre a standup comic and you can‰Ûªt take occasional taunts and heckling, you‰Ûªre in the wrong business. I had a drunk charge the stage one time. The bouncer caught him, and I stood there blowing kisses at him while the bouncer dragged him out and the crowd laughed like hell. Don‰Ûªt play organized hockey, even at the college or social club level if you can‰Ûªt take boos and nasty comments from the stands. And if you‰Ûªre gonna cry every time your coach screams that you‰Ûªre a dumb shit, you need a new hobby.But now I‰Ûªm highly offended. Trumps‰Ûª wreath laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier today made my skin crawl. I come from a military family. My father was a veteran, I couldn‰Ûªt stop sobbing when they gave me the flag that draped his casket at Lincoln National cemetery. I have an uncle who died in a jeep accident in Germany on active duty, and a great uncle who lies at rest somewhere in the USS Arizona at Pearl Harbor, I‰Ûªve seen his name on the wall of the memorial. I lost two close friends who were coworkers in Afghanistan, I attended both of the funerals. Even though I‰Ûªll be 60 next month, I still carry my Vietnam era draft card in my wallet. This is personal to me.It turned my stomach to watch that fat, arrogant orange penguin, who has sacrificed nothing and no one in his life, and who has so little respect for our brave troops that he referred to his swinging lifestyle in New York in the ‰Û÷70s as his own personal Vietnam, even though he received phony deferments to keep from going to Vietnam, wrapping his tiny fingers around that wreath and placing it in front of the tomb of brave, anonymous men who sacrificed everything so that he could grab women by the crotch with impunity. But what really made my blood boil was when a commentator said that the next time he does that at Arlington, he‰Ûªll be saluting instead of putting his hand over his heart! Needless to say, I won‰Ûªt be watching any of those future ceremonies for the next four years.You all know that I have dug into Mein Furor pretty extensively for the last almost 20 months, and usually I just roll with the punches, by trying to heap scorn and sarcasm about everything he says or does. There is so much to hate about him that this website would have to expand to take the diaries if they were all to be chronicled. But these next four years are going to be rough for me, watching him pudge waddle down the steps of Marine One and throwing a salute to the guard soldier at the bottom of the steps, a man who would fight and die for him if Trump ordered it, and a man that Donald J. Trump couldn‰Ûªt give a shit less about.Sorry for the rant, but this has been eating at me for almost three hours now, and I just had to get it out. I don‰Ûªt know what I‰Ûªll write about tomorrow, I had thought about not even turning on the t.v., but somehow I‰Ûªm sure I will, for no better reason than to find something to mock. Thanks to all who read for putting up with this rant!

Title: Eight people 'as rich as poorest half'
Text: Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Superyachts are the calling card of some ultra-wealthy individualsThe world's eight richest individuals have as much wealth as the 3.6bn people who make up the poorest half of the world, according to Oxfam.The charity said its figures, which critics have queried, came from improved data, and the gap between rich and poor was "far greater than feared".The richest eight include Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerberg and Warren Buffett.Mark Littlewood, of the Institute of Economic Affairs, said Oxfam should focus instead on ways to boost growth."As an 'anti-poverty' charity, Oxfam seems to be strangely preoccupied with the rich," said the director-general of the free market think tank.For those concerned with "eradicating absolute poverty completely", the focus should be on measures that encourage economic growth, he added.Ben Southwood, head of research at the Adam Smith Institute, said it was not the wealth of the world's rich that mattered, but the welfare of the world's poor, which was improving every year."Each year we are misled by Oxfam's wealth statistics. The data is fine - it comes from Credit Suisse - but the interpretation is not."Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption Economist Amartya Sen tells Radio 4's Today that economic inequality must be tackled'Elite gathering'Oxfam's report coincides with the start of the World Economic Forum in Davos, a Swiss ski resort. The annual event attracts many of the world's top political and business leaders.Katy Wright, Oxfam's head of global external affairs, said the report helped the charity to "challenge the political and economic elites"."We're under no illusions that Davos is anything other than a talking shop for the world's elite, but we try and use that focus," she added.The world's eight richest billionaires1. Bill Gates (US): co-founder of Microsoft (net worth $75bn)2. Amancio Ortega (Spain): founder of Zara owner Inditex (net worth $67bn)3. Warren Buffett (US): largest shareholder in Berkshire Hathaway (net worth $60.8bn)4. Carlos Slim Helu (Mexico): owner of Grupo Carso (net worth $50bn)5. Jeff Bezos (US): founder and chief executive of Amazon (net worth $45.2bn)6. Mark Zuckerberg (US): co-founder and chief executive of Facebook (net worth $44.6bn)7. Larry Ellison (US): co-founder and chief executive of Oracle (net worth $43.6bn)8. Michael Bloomberg (US): owner of Bloomberg LP (net worth $40bn)Source: Forbes billionaires' list, March 2016UK economist Gerard Lyons said focusing on extreme wealth "does not always give the full picture" and attention should be paid to "making sure the economic cake is getting bigger".However, he said Oxfam was right to single out companies that it believed fuelled inequality with business models that were "increasingly focused on delivering ever-higher returns to wealthy owners and top executives".Oxfam's Ms Wright said economic inequality was fuelling a polarisation in politics, citing Donald Trump's election as US president and the Brexit vote as examples.'Fair share'"People are angry and calling out for alternatives. They're feeling left behind because however hard they work they can't share in their country's growth," she said.The charity is calling for "a more human economy" and is urging governments to crack down on executive pay and tax evasion and impose higher taxes on the wealthy.It also wants business leaders to pay a "fair share of tax" and has urged companies to pay staff the "living wage", which is higher than the government's National Living Wage.Oxfam has produced similar reports for the past four years. In 2016 it calculated that the richest 62 people in the world had as much wealth as the poorest half of the global population.The number had fallen to just eight this year because more accurate data was now available, Oxfam said.It was still the case that the world's richest 1% had as much wealth as the rest of the world combined, Oxfam said.Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg and wife Priscilla ChanSome of the eight richest billionaires have given away tens of billions of dollars. In 2000 Bill Gates and his wife Melinda set up a private foundation that has an endowment of more than $44bn.In 2015 Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Priscilla Chan pledged to give away 99% of their net worth in their lifetimes, which equated to about $45bn based on the value of Facebook shares at the time.It takes cash and assets worth $71,600 to get into the top 10%, and $744,396 to be in the top 1%.Oxfam's report is based on data from Forbes and the annual Credit Suisse Global Wealth datebook, which gives the distribution of global wealth going back to 2000.The survey uses the value of an individual's assets, mainly property and land, minus debts, to determine what he or she "owns". The data excludes wages or income.The methodology has been criticised as it means that a student with high debts, but with high future earning potential, for example, would be considered poor under the criteria used.
Description: Oxfam research finds the eight richest billionaires have as much wealth as 3.6 billion people combined.

Title: ‰Û÷Hard to get inside Mosul, over 1mn people still trapped amid op‰Ûª ‰ÛÒ Oxfam representative to RT
Text: Humanitarian organizations face serious difficulties in delivering aid to people inside Iraq‰Ûªs Mosul amid the US-backed operation against Islamic State, Oxfam spokesman who returned from Iraq told RT. Over 1 million people are still trapped in the city."Unfortunately, it‰Ûªs very difficult for humanitarian agencies like Oxfam to get into Mosul itself," Kai Tabacek, Oxfam's digital press officer said in an interview to RT. He returned just a month ago from the area of Irbil, which is 90 kilometers from Mosul.Read moreAccording to Tabacek, some 100,000 people have managed to flee the violence in Mosul, yet approximately 10 times more are still in the city and facing a ‰ÛÏdire humanitarian situation.‰ÛAfter almost two months of operation to liberate Mosul ‰ÛÏwe have more than 100,000 people who have fled the city and surrounding areas,‰Û the Oxfam representative said. ‰ÛÏStill more than a million people, we believe, are trapped inside Mosul and they are at risk from being caught by sniper fire, explosive devices. And it's really important that all sides in this conflict provide safe escape routes for those people to leave.‰ÛMosul was captured by Islamic State (IS, formerly ISIS/ISIL) back in 2014 and later turned into a self-proclaimed capital of the jihadists in Iraq. The operation to retake the key city started on October 17, with tens of thousands of Iraqi military, special forces and militias taking part. The mission is also supported by the US-led international coalition.‰ÛÏThe situation is not great, particularly with winter arriving in Iraq,‰Û Tabacek said. Yet ‰ÛÏso far most of the displaced families leaving Mosul have been able to access some form of assistance from Oxfam and from others [humanitarian organizations]."Read moreThe Oxfam press officer also noted that it‰Ûªs crucial for all sides to avoid using heavy weaponry inside the city since it puts civilian lives at risk.‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs very worrying when there is a conflict that close to where the people are living and we‰Ûªve seen in other places and in Mosul so far, the way ISIS seem willing to use people as human shields,‰Û Tabacek warned.He also said that liberating Mosul won‰Ûªt automatically eliminate the humanitarian crisis in the area: ‰ÛÏMore than 3 million people that are displaced in northern Iraq. And that‰Ûªs not only from Mosul, that's a number of other areas that have been recaptured in the last few years. This is a crisis that is not going to go away anytime soon,‰Û Tabacek said.Meanwhile, the operation to retake Mosul has slowed down in the past weeks since the Iraqi army and militias are going deeper into the city. In addition, an early December report by Debkafiles, a military intelligence news site with links to the Israeli military, said Islamic State is now mulling to stay put in their Iraqi stronghold. According to the report, a delegation of IS commanders arrived in Mosul on December 4, to discuss synchronizing the city defenses with those of Raqqa in Syria. Mosul commanders have ‰ÛÏchanged course about leaving the city and decided to stay put,‰Û the paper said.READ MORE: Pentagon pens ground op plans for Mosul as campaign falters ‰ÛÒ DEBKA
Description: Humanitarian organizations face serious difficulties in delivering aid to people inside Iraq‰Ûªs Mosul amid the US-backed operation against Islamic State, Oxfam spokesman who returned from Iraq told RT. Over 1 million people are still trapped in the city.

Title: The Every Student Succeeds Act will Fail - The Boston Globe
Text: Across the country, schools and school districts have begun to implement the Every Student Succeeds Act of 2015. The law is the latest reauthorization of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, first passed in 1965. Yet, despite the fanfare and promise to usher in a new era, this newest version ‰ÛÓ like so many federal and state schemes to implement high standards for student learning ‰ÛÓ will fail. The regulatory process associated with implementation will inevitably corrupt the law‰Ûªs intent.I have witnessed this again and again in my 35 years as a teacher ‰ÛÓ a front-row seat from which I have viewed the deadening impact on schools and classrooms of standards as regulatory tools. At the same time, however, I have also been inspired by the inventive ways that school-level educators and communities have used similar standards to foster powerful learning.In 1989, I joined a circle of colleagues and parents frustrated by the focus on testing of the well-regarded high school in our suburban community near Albany, N.Y. At the time, New York State‰Ûªs curriculum consisted of thick manuals with long lists of learning objectives and a battery of tests, the vaunted Regents Exams. Our small group asked: How can we engage students in learning more fully beyond a narrow desire to ace the exam?AdvertisementOver the course of several years we designed and launched an alternative school-within-a-school, in which tests took a back seat to projects designed to simulate real world problems. Each semester, students in the Bethlehem Lab School presented their work before a panel of adults drawn from the community. The high stakes of a juried exhibition pushed our students to focus, and the complex nature of the work forced them to think more deeply and broadly than they were accustomed.Get Arguable in your inbox: Jeff Jacoby on everything from politics to pet peeves to the passions of the day. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters hereOur students didn‰Ûªt take Regents Exams. At the time, students in New York State could opt for a ‰ÛÏlocal‰Û diploma instead. We chose this lower status designation as an entire school to free ourselves to create a more demanding curriculum, based on New York State‰Ûªs own learning standards. It turned out that at the back of all those thick curriculum books put out by the state stood an elegantly simple list of 10 goals. It fit on one page. It was our constitution. And though the Regents curriculum was, theoretically, based on the 10 goals, the process of parsing out learning objectives in each subject and the demands of psychometricians for reliability and validity resulted in a curriculum overweight with content, instruction focused on memorization, and tests that rewarded students able to retain lots and lots of information. The system demanded compliance more than it fostered learning.Several years later, I was invited to join a new public charter school in Massachusetts as principal teacher. The Francis W. Parker Charter Essential School was founded by parents and educators who pioneered an approach to standards and assessment in which each student continuously created original work assembled into a portfolio. Revision was encouraged, and standards were printed on posters hung on the walls of every classroom. Students worked hard to improve their essays, lab reports, and projects until they met the standards, and when they demonstrated to their teachers and classmates through a live exhibition that the standards were met, they were promoted.Those were heady times in Massachusetts. The Education Reform Act of 1993 that enabled charter schools also promised a statewide assessment system to include portfolios and other forms of ‰ÛÏauthentic‰Û assessment like those at the Lab School and the Parker School. But first, under political pressure, regulators were compelled to generate thick manuals of finely parsed learning objectives. Then, the psychometricians went to work figuring out how to measure learning. Shortly, the Department of Education rolled out a battery of on-demand tests, with the grandiose title of the Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System, or what we know today more often as the MCAS. No portfolios and nothing authentic about them. Again, compliance ruled the day. Teachers and students would have to fall in line.2001 saw passage of the No Child Left Behind Act. Standards as regulatory tool, in force in some states, became the law of the land. They called it accountability.AdvertisementIn 2006, after 25 years in schools, I reinvented myself as an assistant professor at a nearby university. I wanted to know: Were my experiences part of a larger pattern? I quickly learned two things. The first is that there is a boatload of research showing that accountability has narrowed the curriculum nationwide and turned schools serving our nation‰Ûªs neediest students into test prep factories. And the second is legions of education researchers have seized on the rising tide of test data to answer their questions. The answers are often simplistic in ways that belie the complexity of schools and classrooms, while legitimizing the testing culture.As evidence has mounted that the accountability regime is turning many schools into test prep centers, advocates for accountability have argued that schools need not slavishly teach to the test. Instead, they say, schools should offer a robust curriculum with demanding instruction, and the tests will take care of themselves. This sounds like common sense, but in a study I just completed with Megin Charner-Laird of Salem State University and Stacy Szczesiul of the University of Massachusetts Lowell, we found that schools with reliably high test scores ‰ÛÓ while not teaching to the test per se ‰ÛÓ tend to teach a limited range of skills required for the test. Teachers and administrators told us they would aspire to something more, but this is what the system demands.At schools like the Lab School and the Parker School, demanding standards, attached to assessments that rely on judgment, foster powerful learning. At the system level, strict reliance on measurement, where judgment is expunged as a contaminant, has served to narrow learning and diminish student engagement.The Every Student Succeeds Act, or ESSA as it is known, holds on to this fundamental element of the accountability movement like a dog does a bone. Meanwhile, a Gallup Student Poll administered last fall shows 68 percent of high school juniors unengaged in school. Portfolios, juried exhibitions, external audits, peer review ‰ÛÓ all of which rely on judgment informed with evidence ‰ÛÓ have been marginalized at the system level, but they are exactly what works at the local level in pushing students to think deeply and engage in learning. Perhaps after ESSA fails to deliver, we will get the message, and a new policy regime will be driven not by the question how do we measure X, but, instead, how do we engage and inspire children and youth?James Nehring is a former Fulbright Scholar and an associate professor of education at the University of Massachusetts Lowell. He is the author, most recently, of ‰ÛÏWhy Teach? Notes and Questions from a Life in Education.‰Û
